About San Cristóbal de las Casas

San Cristóbal de las Casas is a magical colonial city in the Chiapas highlands where living Maya cultures, cobblestone streets, indigenous markets, and cloud forests create one of Mexico's most atmospheric destinations. It's the gateway to Palenque, Sumidero Canyon, and stunning jungle waterfalls.

Practical Information

Frequently Asked Questions About San Cristóbal de las Casas

Is San Cristóbal safe for travelers?
San Cristóbal is one of Mexico's safest tourist destinations. The colonial center is very walkable day and night. Surrounding villages welcome respectful tourists. Exercise normal caution, don't display expensive items, and you'll have no problems. The bigger concern is altitude adjustment (7,000 feet) for the first day or two.
What's the weather like?
Due to altitude (7,000 feet), San Cristóbal has spring-like weather year-round. Days are mild (65-75°F) but mornings and evenings are cold (40-50°F). Bring layers, a warm jacket, and rain gear (especially May-October). It's much cooler than coastal Mexico—pack accordingly.
How do I get to San Cristóbal?
Fly to Tuxtla Gutiérrez (TGZ, 1 hour drive) or smaller San Cristóbal airport (SZT) with connections through Mexico City. ADO buses from Oaxaca (10 hours), Mexico City (12 hours), and Palenque (5 hours) are comfortable. From Cancún/Riviera Maya, fly via Mexico City.
How much time should I spend?
Minimum 3-4 days: one day for the city, one for Chamula/Zinacantán villages, and one for a major day trip (Sumidero or start of Palenque trip). A week allows Palenque with overnight, Lagos de Montebello, and relaxed exploration. Two weeks lets you fully explore Chiapas.
Can I visit indigenous villages respectfully?
Yes, but respect is essential. Never photograph people without permission (and expect to pay a small tip). No photography inside Chamula church. Dress modestly. Hire local guides who understand protocols. These are living communities, not tourist attractions—approach with humility.
What should I buy in San Cristóbal?
Chiapan amber (buy from reputable shops to avoid fakes), textiles and huipiles from indigenous weavers, locally roasted coffee, handmade ceramics, and posh (traditional wool garments). The market around Santo Domingo is excellent for crafts. Buy directly from artisans when possible.
